summary: Ben Cash (Viggo Mortensen), his wife Leslie and their six children live deep in the wilderness of Washington state. Isolated from society, Ben and Leslie devote their existence to raising their kids -- educating them to think critically, training them to be physically fit and athletic, guiding them in the wild without technology and demonstrating the beauty of co-existing with nature. When Leslie dies suddenly, Ben must take his sheltered offspring into the outside world for the first time.

0 stars
Simply excellent, a must see! A really well written story with really engaging characters. Acting and direction is great throughout!
Touching, layered, contemplative. An impressively multi-faceted take on what is mostly a cliché family drama.

In Captain Fantastic, set in the dense forest of Washington state, Ben (Viggo Mortensen) lives off the land with his six children, providing them with a traditional education as well as survival skills.  However, when their hospitalized mother dies, they are forced to enter the mainstream world and consider the possibility of assimilation.  The subject matter throughout is interesting, the scenery is beautiful, and the script poses many interesting questions, including the most compelling – can we be critical, objective thinkers after being influenced by our parents and community with regards to religious affiliations, political allegiances, social issues, and other moral matters?  If nothing else, Captain Fantastic is sure to spark debate.
This is an all time favorite movie. If you are a free thinking family, unschooling, or otherwise open minded, you will LOVE this!
What a conflict of lives, surely this is the movie that the young generation should watch, and let them decide their path. Amazing, generous and enlightening.

Not always that you catch a movie with such an interesting concept but it also pulls it off. CF leans in to its "weirdness" with charm and wit whilst not being afraid to comment on the strange nature of it's family. It's quite hard to understand the message as it's convoluted and seems to imply that self sustainability is possible within "the system" but there are other alternatives worth exploring

5 years ago- A powerful, thought-provoking film with gorgeous settings is bursting with brilliant acting. While Viggo's tough and playful Father leads the way, a group of child actors and Frank Langella make every performance worth watching.

The strongest card in Captain Fantastic's deck is how well it flows. Rarely is there an uninteresting or non entertaining moment. As the movie deals heavily in philosophy, I appreciated that the writers stick to the script in some spots and also poke holes in it in other spots. Philosophy can never be about what is right or what is wrong as it exists in relativity. The film never expects Viggo's character to be anything different than he is and the same goes for the members of his family on the opposite end of the spectrum. It does expect however that they adjust to each other and see the faults in their own beliefs. Moral of the story - people are different and can simultaneously want the best outcomes despite the means of achieving those outcomes being wildly different. That's not to say this movie is perfect. It's not. There are plenty of small annoyances - mostly implications like traditional school, video games, and television make you stupid (scenes with Viggo's sister's kids at their house). But the only truly obtuse part of this movie is its economics. The family may have been able to live off the land for the most part and make enough for everything else by selling knick knacks as is implied at the beginning of the movie...but then when it comes time to drive hundreds of miles and the eldest son to hop on a plane, the film doesn't care to comment except by saying "stick it to the man"...what? That cash is coming from father-in-law who is this movie's "man" or from thin air.

The movie is about a communist who brainwashes his children to be Marxists who celebrate the birth of Noam Chomsky instead 'an elf' (Jesus Christ). The interesting part about the film is how deluded communists are. Not the father, Ben, the deluded writers, producers, and reviewers of this movie. These people fancy themselves to be brilliant philosophers that are a counter-culture to "the man" (Christian capitalist society). Ben is rebelling against this society by raising his kids off grid, stealing from grocery stores, killing other peoples livestock, and looking down the stupid peasants that just don't get how crappy it is to live in capitalist society. The irony is, Christian conservatives teach their kids at home. Communists raise their kids in public schools. Christian conservatives teach their kids to live off the land. Communists teach their kids to live off of food stamps, or the wealth of their parents. Christian conservatives have lots of children. Communists abort their children. Christian conservatives live in rural areas. Communists live in Urban ghettos, or gated communities near the coasts. The movie reviews reveal how delusional communists are. They don't read books, they riot, and parrot big lies from the corporate media and the bankers they own them. They aren't against the establishment, they are tools of the establishment. They aren't anti-facsists, they are fascists. They don't love the bill of rights, they ignore the bill of rights. They only thing accurate about Marxists, like Ben, is his narcissism, his irrational hatred of Christians, and his boastful attitude that he is superior to everyone else. This is probably the dumbest movie I have ever seen, in large part because it is so unrealistic. People like Ben exist only in the imaginations of pampered college grads who skimmed parts "The Communist Manifesto" and watched lectures about Jean Jaques-Rousseau's "Discourse on Inequality" for their political philosophy course in college. This movie is a delusion of grandeur.

Excelente actuación de Vigo, una familia de salvajes, gente que se acostumbro a vivir de la naturaleza en el medio de un bosque tiene que ir a la ciudad por la muerte de la madre de la familia, una aventura fantástica con una fuerte carga emocional, entretenida y dramática al mismo tiempo.
Solid film that effectively "both sides" the ideas of home schooling and living off the grid. Viggo's Oscar nomination was well deserved.
Philosophical and thought-provoking
A great movie that shows the remarkable difference between the "couch-potato" youth of today and children who have been taught the art of survival.

Very well crafted and acted film. And it's just short of a masterpiece. But most reviewers here missed the obvious: Ben is a totalitarian monster.

Kielyr explains the movie to us when forced by her dad to explicate Lolita.  And Ben finally sees it himself in the end:  "It was a beautiful mistake."

Uma grande obra sem dúvidas, uma carga emocional muito forte, atores tão jovens mas com tanto sentimento, é realmente linda a trama. Me fez pensar em como a sociedade moderna realmente é autodestrutiva, a vida no campo apresenta muito mais diversidade em um contexto geral, sendo que na natureza você experimenta a ação real, enquanto no conforto de nossas casas, só fazemos tais aventuras através de videogames. Muito empenhados em afazeres domésticos, o que nós não fazemos em uma semana eles fazem em um dia. Todos os personagens são antros do conhecimento, com um conhecimento sobre a sociedade, politica e historia, que é um absurdo. E ainda eles tem que brigar pra decidir qual o idioma será falado, eu mal falo dois, e eu os vi falando em uns três. Varias regras malucas mas que são seguidas por todos com uma harmonia muito pacifica. Desfecho perfeito, muito certos de seus ideais.

"Captain Fantastic" is audacious and seems to revel in its own contradictions. Some have criticized it for being heavy on didacticism. Perhaps. But I think it realistically shows the drawbacks of living off the grid. Sooner of later, most of us have to find a way to coexist with the rest of the world--especially if we have children.
Is Mortenson's Ben a dictator? Yes. His kids are victims. But as he softens up in the final acts, we realize that what we think is best for our kids is often misguided. 
Actually, were it not for the language and nudity, this could have been marketed as a family film. It's too bad, because I think it would stimulate some meaningful discussions between parents and kids.

Absolutely loved this movie! It's about an unconventional family that lives off grid and survives off of the wild. They are homeschooled kids, but they know way more than any public school could teach them. But the death of the mother forces them out of their comfort zones and into the realization of society. It is truly inspirational. Has emotional moments, funny moments, and completely ridiculous moments. It shows you that not everyone has to raise their kids or live all the same way. The acting was on point and the cinematography was beautiful! Definitely recommend this one!

How do you give a movie zero stars? Hated it from the get-go. Watched it for 25 minutes and could not take anymore. Completely confused by all the good reviews. Worst movie we have tried to watch in a long time. Pretentious, unrealistic, unlikeable characters….teaching his kids to steal, kill someone else’s livestock, etc etc….ridiculous.

This movie inspired me to read more, to reflect on what we should really value in life, and to strive to be active rather than passive in our choices. I emotionally understood the central conflict i.e. how to balance giving your children the best start without ostracizing them to the point they struggle to participate in normal society. It did paint an idealized view of living off the grid rather than include some of the more mundane issues that would surely arise in daily life, but I felt this was forgivable. The only part I truly take issue with is the decision by Bo at the end to travel to Namibia after he [put (his) finger on a map]. Whilst Namibia is actually a really good fit for him to develop as a young man given his current skill set, I felt this decision should have been the result of careful research by him and his father rather than just made on a whim. What would have happened if his finger had landed on Japan, or France for example? However, that such a minor point caught my attention is testimony to how cohesive and engaging the movie is overall.

Thought provoking, unashamed in the way it feels, and performed to the highest degree by its lead. 'Captain Fantastic' is a film that touches the hearts of those who watch it, and leaves the viewer feeling that there is always something out there waiting to be discovered. This film made me think of certain things differently; and in the end, isn't that what every film should strive to accomplish - make the viewer think?
As the title says, fantastic.
Even the most extreme off the grid parents wouldn’t be this ridiculous. Ben is a narcissist who feeds his addiction with the authoritarian rule of his kids.
Very strong cast in this movie however it feels like it could have been better.  At times it feels like a liberals wet dream manifesting on film.

Much less than meets the eye. Without the language (outrageously vulgar) this is a children's film for the flower generation's descendants. The twin girls and the youngest daughter still evoke a warm surge of silent laughter when I remember them. The contrasting fathers tell a tale of opposite extremes of empathy and compassion. Viggo's character seeks to alienate all present and unaccounted for. His lack of understanding or tact is a masterpiece of witless behavior.

I really enjoyed this movie. The kids were all great, full of personality and each one so different. Viggo Mortensen was the perfect pick for this role. The rest of the cast was also well chosen. At the end of it you had to wonder if he didn't have the better way to raise kids.  Maybe people will get their kids off video games and cell phones and after seeing this.

Very well acted, particularly from Viggo, but the film is very uncritical of Ben or the methods he uses to raise kids. While it's happy to aggressively mock typical societal consumerist norms and stereotypical Christian views, it does not cast a critical light on Ben's methods for raising his children. The director was very much promoting the philosophies and methodologies of Ben while stomping down Christianity and modern societal culture and it's hard to take this seriously without a balanced critical light of Ben.

A difficult film to wrap your head around. Watching this film provoked questions that inspired, scared and excited me, as well as brilliantly addressing the burdens of capitalism that unknowingly oppress the majority every waking day. The forest scenery is stunning. The city spectacle is honest, tailored to Ross' aesthetic - realistic & gritty. The film puts a spotlight on Ben, the protagonist played by Viggo Mortensen, a once regular guy who grew tired of being the state's puppet. Ben rejected societal obligations and norms by creating his own way of living. Although Ben's parenting style is controversial, Ross persuades the spectator to favour it over the 'normal' parenting styles that the spectator is likely familiar with. One way in which Ross encourages his spectator's to favour Ben's choice of parenting, is by displaying the positive outcomes. One example of this is when when Ben's eight-year-old daughter, played by Shree Crooks, succeeds the knowledge of Harper's children, who represent the modern youth of America. Through this comparison, Ross critique's the impact of technology, unhealthy eating and the education system on the youth of today. Unfortunately, the plot was slightly stretched out, in my opinion, despite the fact that I continued to be fascinated with what was happening on screen at every moment! Watching this film, you will be absorbed into a journey where your vulnerability will reveal itself as your emotions cross different roads. I thoroughly relished in exploring an unpopular ideology, which unlocked my mind, aiding me in the discovery of opinions I wasn't aware that I even held.

Very odd, but engaging survivalist/family bonding movie. Some of it is disturbing and some of it is funny. Much of it is absurd, too. It drags a little when it lingers on nature's beauty  but overall moves along to its absurd conclusion.

A unique film that shows the reality of mental health even when treated it can be unsettling.  A family goes off grid and thrives as survivalist and intellectual but it takes a tragic turn to force the realization that this life could be fatal.

Can't figure out what people like about this film.  It's a generally boring story about a overly propagandized family. Sorta fitting for our times, I guess. Gave it an extra str for Vigo. Even he doesn't make it worth wasting your time on.
Beautiful movie, just see it

Also, I had to CTFU at the funeral scene when the father gives his eulogy. I have the exact same objections to being buried in casket and rotting in the ground for all eternity LMFAO. Cremate me, too!
An ingenious thought provoking movie that will offend some people. Loved it.
20 minutes into this movie was too much. What a waste of 20 minutes! Horrible plot, cast...  you name it it was awful! No words to describe how bad this was.
A progressive fabulist's idea of a perfect family, unrealistic and unconvincing.

This movie is the wet dream of every Che Guevara tee shirted philosophy 101 student. The film is about a trust fund kid who takes her fathers money and moves to the woods with her dogmatically anarcho-communist husband, who is the smartest, wisest and most capable man who ever lived. She is bipolar and he keeps her from getting medical help because he knows better than all of modern science, knows how to do quantum physics, and can recite Noam Chomsky on cue. They raise a bunch of children to hate capitalist society, especially Christians. Then despite the husband being right about everything, the wife kills herself due to untreated bipolar disorder. Now the husband must travel across fascist America with his Marxist children to steal his wife's body from her family, cremate it, and flush it down a toilet. The husband makes sure to tell his kids never to lie all the while lying and stealing to get their way. This movie has all the smugness and righteousness of Christian cinema hits like God Is Not Dead 2 and the shallow straw maned characters of a 80s era North Korean propaganda film. If you don't like this movie you probably either have a low IQ or you attended any history class covering the horrors of the 20th Century...
Loved it! I just wish there was more.

Absolutely loved it. The blending of valuable life lessons and some traditional lifestyle choices with practical thought-out choices which take the best of the current lifestyle landscape is the ticket. You won't regret seeing this film!

Do yourself a favor; save two miserable hours and go watch Leave No Trace instead. You'll get the same premise without a completely farcical plot from minute one. That being said, Captain Fantastic is a good film to play in the background while you scroll through DIY birdhouses and granola recipes, only to tune in every 10 minutes or so to pat yourself on the back about how you're challenging societal norms. All the philosophical name-dropping tries to hold this shamble of a film together. Unfortunately, it plays out as sanctimonious and contrived. See Mr. Ross, I can use big words too.
As someone who finds the definition of tradition as being the opposite of practical, I really liked this movie, but of course I am biased.

Definitely had its moments. Viggo is typically superb. Can't help but feel that a few elements of the film felt hackneyed or like simple archetypes. The whole conflict with the rebellious son felt like I'd seen every scene involving him a hundred times. I think that the most interesting part of the film was the character of Ben, which covered so many different emotions and actions to great effect. However, looking past the main character was a sense of predictability in most areas. Most of the humour worked well, with not too many jokes that fell entirely flat. The emotional moments of the film varied between being stirring and being formulaic and nauseating. I found the ending to be slightly unfitting at first, in terms of how it ties up the main conflict involving Ben. Overall, though, definitely worth a watch and interesting to many different audiences.

This movie was phenomenal. If you like the beaten path, you won't like this movie. If you feel the need to fit in and not rock the boat, you won't like this movie. If you are a deep thinking nature loving free spirit: WATCH THIS MOVIE.

Simply dreadful. Awful. Terrible. There is absolutely nothing believable about this family or its father. The first five minutes of the movie, where the teenage son wrestles and kills a deer with his bare hands (!!)--and then eats the heart with his dad--gives you a preview of the absurdities ahead. And ten year old kids spouting Marxism, dialectical materialism, etc? We are expected to swallow this nonsense?
A silly, contrived movie that has no redeeming character or interest. The father should be in a mental institution.
This movie showed both the light and dark sides of off-grid living. The acting, script, and plot were all on point. If you like into the wild, you'll love this.
A good premise with poor details.  Hippie parenting seen through a capitalist eye.

A story of a family living out their radical ideals and then being forced to face the flaws in these ideals due to a "tragedy" (that is probably a result of taking things to an extreme). When they enter the social world, the father (who is "captain fantastic) is initially smug about their "superior" lifestyle, angry at any suggestion of compromise, but then things happen which make him question his decisions. The development of his character is what's most compelling because we see a black and white mentality begin to show nuance. The drama feels like antics that could've been more humorous but often feel pretentious instead, and the other characters feel a little too much like stereotypes (but it seems it's through the eyes of the protagonist). The story is definitely entertaining and worth a watch.
Very different and unique, some parts can be disturbing, just don't look away
Viggo Mortensen gives a spectacular performance in a movie that is both interesting and heartfelt. It's worth checking out considering the outstanding acting and thought-provoking themes.

Did someone already mention thought-provoking? Yeah? Ok. So do I.
Leaves you out in the wild, thinking: about ways of living; about the influence of society on your ways of living; about finding a decent spot for your ways of living somewhere in between.
Thought provoking movie about where a parent should draw the line between nurturing their children's independence, and protecting their children from danger and mental trauma.

Captain Fantastic straripa di informazioni e la netta contrapposizione tra i due schieramenti non limita lo spettatore dall'analisi critica di pregi e difetti.
La potenza di questo film è la credibilità di ogni conversazione, di ogni opinione e di ogni pensiero; tutto è valido e non un singolo elemento è fuori posto.
Viggo Mortensen è splendido interprete e vero "capitano" della sua ciurma ma sia la regia che la sceneggiatura sono degli esempi di capacità e di talento.
Ulteriore nota di merito per la colonna sonora.
Uno dei film con più sfaccettature che io abbia mai visto.
Funny and endearing.
Entertaining but flattened. However, there are the most persuasive traces of a history of mental illness.
An anti-hero story of one man and his family escaping their way out life in the woods.

Melhor filme da história, pra mim. Se ele tem algum defeito passa despercebido porquê o filme é simplesmente mágico. A atuação de Viggo é genial e a das crianças também, adorei e recomendo a todos assistirem.

Captain Fantastic is a moving Roadtrip Movie of the other kind. The Movie has good Performances to offer especially from Viggo Mortensen and George McKay the rest ,which is primarily the Kids play rather good as well and it is an easy watch. We Witness some pretty good Filmmaking here as well.
RATING: 4,3
Now this was something else.
It's my FAVORITE movie of all times

I am not sure if it is because I am already of a certain mindset, however this is one of my most favourite films. So refreshing to see others sharing my perspective on "humanity" and how far wrong we've come. Captain fantastic is truly fantastic. Stick it to the man.

I've never seen a movie quite like this. Though evasive of traditional plotlines, it keeps the audience engaged through its beautiful characters and fascinating premise. Captain Fantastic is eccentric yet familiar, poignant yet celebratory. Perfect dialogue, props, and casting. I could watch it again and again.
Good movie starring the guy from lord of the rings.
If we put aside some of the forced drama, this is a beautiful movie and makes you question what your life all about.

Captain Fantastic is basically the good version of 'Leave No Trace', which is a below average film. This film has some quality humour, the characters were good, the acting was strong, and the plot was decent. Good old Viggo, haven't seen him since LOTR. It's a pretty unique film that captures the difficulties of parenting and the problems of raising children in isolation. The cinematography was sleek, and the soundtrack was pleasant. Captain Fantastic isn't the most believable due to all of the children being experts on all sorts of topics just from reading, but it is worth a watch as it was entertaining.
Touching, layered, contemplative. An impressively multi-faceted take on what is mostly a cliché family drama.
One of the best movies I have seen. Funny, emotional and brings you deep into the movie. Grabs bottle of wine, sit back and enjoy....
Inspiring, heartfelt story.
I wish I was raised in a family like this.
Interesting story this one told about a father raising his children far from civilization and makes you wonder how much of the world do you let in and how much to keep out.

This movie won't give you the laughs that the trailer shows and is a little off putting at first but it is a good movie and worth watching. Viggo Mortensen is great in it and so are all the kid actors.

Almost The Graduate for the present day, or an intriguing bookend double feature. You need a college education (or hippie parents?) to follow some of the philosophical/political leanings presented by the characters -- but intelligence is present, and not just in the adults featured -- How often does Hollywood allow that? Full frontal by Viggo Mortensen --has that been mentioned by everyone reviewing this?

Fantastic ensemble family-drama about the dangers of extremes. Ben's realizations of the impact of his and his wife's decision to raise their family off the grid is pivotal and important. It's  an important and original drama that's well shot and acted. All of the child actors get their moments to shine. It's mature message of knowing and admitting when you're wrong, or have gone too far runs deep. A wonderful and bold  surprise that ventures from the whimsical fable I expected.
This was really really good. I laughet, I thought about it and I enjoyed it ...
I absolutely love this film up there with my favorites.

Occasionally moving comedic drama that ultimately doesn't hit the heights of the superior Leave No Trace (which covers similar ground), lacking the latter's heft and transcendence. It doesn't really do justice the idea of the off-grid lifestyle, and nor does it properly interrogate it - meaning it ultimately feels more than a little naive. Mortensen shines throughout.
Beautifully written, beautiful acted, and beautiful made; just a genuinely beautiful film.
A hidden gem of a film that is quirky but heartfelt.
This is a movie that is not afraid to tackle heavy themes. Keeps you thinking as any good movie should and doesn't give you all the answers just as life.

Absolutely loved this movie. The kind of film you think about weeks later. Definitely anti- Cristian/ religious, but its’ message about humanity is clear and beautiful. Most of the bad reviews from the public here are from offended Jesus freaks or people who criticized his parenting decisions completely missing the message of the film.

Though I really enjoy Viggo Mortensen as an actor, Captain Fantastic was certainly not one of his best efforts--such as the Green Book. The entire premise of this film was questionable.  The beginning of the film was strange, to say the least.  This "survivalist" movie was contrived and had questionable scenes.  There was at least one nude scene that could have been done far more tastefully.  It was a Godless contrived movie that went out of its way to make fun of Christianity.
A beautiful piece of storytelling. When Scorsese says that Marvel movies aren't cinema, I feel that this film is abundant in what he finds lacking from those films.
Engrossing movie, a little to preachy at parts
I loved it so much I've seen it eight times
The whole idea that idealism can replace family values bothered me, but the movie was entertaining.
Excelente película te hace analizar la sociedad actual de que vivimos con un consumismo atroz

Viggo Mortensen terrific performance, among the rest of the cast members, is just the tip of the iceberg of this unconventional and highly satisfying touching-comedy, written and successfully directed by Matt Ross, with a unique focus, view and tone that'll provide enough identity and style to endure among other "odd" indie flicks, approaching themes such as social commentary, true freedom and the need for an exit of the world's exhausting conventionality.

Viggo Mortensen terrific performance, among the rest of the cast members, is just the tip of the iceberg of this unconventional and highly satisfying touching-comedy, written and successfully directed by Matt Ross, with a unique focus, view and tone that'll provide enough identity and style to endure among other "odd" indie flicks, approaching themes such as social commentary, true freedom and the need for an exit of the world's exhausting conventionality.
Brilliant, emotional, and thought provoking movie. The acting was fantastic.
Well done. Good story that is told well. Great performances by the entire family.
Horrible, disturbing movie. I would not recommend it to anyone.
I loved this film, a utopian dream full of real life lessons. Laughter, tears and teachings. beautifully shot and acted

It's often hard to find films that explore parenting with sensitivity and without assigning blame to one parent or another, see Kramer vs. Kramer (1979) also, this is a film that manages to do it. Having seen 28 Hotel Rooms (2012) and having not been particularly impressed I didn't expect much from director Matt Ross coming into this film but he tells a story that feels very personal here and has a sure eye for repressed tensions. Viggo Mortensen seemed to be the main story with this film as he received his second of three nominations for Best Actor for playing the lead role in this film and it's true, he carries the film. This is not a film for those who like very plotty pictures or don't enjoy aggressive but contemplative stories this may be a difficult watch but if you come in prepared for that you will be greeted by a fantastic film.

Ben Cash, Viggo Mortensen, is raising his six children as a single father after the suicide of his wife Leslie, Trin Miller, as they live off the grid in the wilderness and learn about revolutionary, liberal politics. Cash and his children must travel into regular society in order to attend their mother's funeral. On their road trip they encounter the positives of civilian life as his eldest son Bodevan, George MacKay, experiences his first relationship and his most rebellious child Rellian, Nicholas Hamilton, questions his authority. He comes into conflict with both his father in law Jack, Frank Langella, and his sister Harper, Kathryn Hahn, and her husband Dave, Steve Zahn, who urge him to give his children normal upbringings. 

The film is very good at presenting both sides of the argument as we see the positives of Cash's way of life, his daughter Zaja, Shree Crooks, can recite the Bill of Rights, but also how he encourages them to shoplift and how they struggle to interact with their peers. You understand the frustrations of Harper and Dave as they attempt to reason with the often fiery and inconsiderate Cash but they also condescend him and in the end come to understand how important Cash was to Leslie. The dinner table scene in which he references how Dave referred to Leslie as a "bitch" during their last encounter, it is implied she became overly zealous in a conversation about children eating sugar, displays the differences in the way these people choose to act. At the end of the day Harper and Dave care about Cash and his children and their largest concern is to make their lives better.

Mortensen's performance is a large part of why the conflict works as well as he is at once infuriating in his self righteousness but sensitive in his treatment of his children's education. When he fantasizes about his wife we see him tear up and the first hints of a buried vulnerability begins to appear as we know that even he questions his way life despite outwardly broadcasting the idea that he is steadfastly committed to it. He has the usual Academy Award "commitment" scene when he appears unnecessarily nude in one scene but other than that the performance is largely without vanity as Mortensen shows he is willing to question the liberal beliefs that he probably holds in real life. 

The young actors playing the children also do a great job as rising star MacKay performs well as the confused young son coming of age. Watching him begin an innocent flirtation with a sweet, experienced young woman and misinterpret her signals completely was lovely as we see him step outside of his father's shadow. The two actors that surprised me most with their nuanced dramatic performances were Hahn and Zahn as the perplexed parents just trying to get along with a difficult relative. The friction between the three characters is made more potent by Hahn's believable reactions and her sudden outburst was shocking and emotional.

I really liked this film, despite Guardian critic Peter Bradshaw's criticism of it, because it offered an interesting analysis of differences in parenting style and featured great performances. It's relatively short and very watchable even if you can't feel sympathy for the main character.

It's awkward, it's funny; it's quirky, deep and moving -- I don't know how he managed to combine those traits into a film that flows so wonderfully, but Matt Ross' has done it. The entire cast is great and nail their roles as the unique bunch of characters, but I have to give extra credit to Mortensen here who is, as usual, outstanding and brings a certain sensitivity and believability to a complex man when everything he stands for, everything he's taught his kids, is brought into question. Interesting premise - a pair of new age survivalists raise six children without normal contact with society. However, the movie becomes burdened by trying really hard to fit in all the little idiosyncrasies of this family's life, so that the story about the characters ends up taking a back seat.  I was also disappointed that any doubts/questions about whether it was right to raise their children this way - as hardcore new age survivalists - seemed to be summarily dealt with rather than being meaningfully explored.  The father and father-in-law relationship was interesting and certainly deserved more exploration.  Still, it was fun to watch and the plot held together well enough if you can suspend disbelief through much of it.

The indie with the golden heart that could grant a nom.
CAPTAIN FANTASTIC
Indie movies aren't appreciated enough and it's sad that sometimes it takes an Oscar nom for people to get interested in them. In fact, there's no rule that says you have to like movies whose budget is over $30 million but unfortunately it's tough for the general public to come across with smaller movies. Therefore, and though these are the more marketable indies, when the Academy nominates films like "Moonlight", "The Lobster" and "Captain Fantastic" they're doing a sort of cultural service. This latter picture is one of the biggest surprises of the year. It's a deeply moving feature film, shot beautifully and acted even more so by everyone involved. It's almost documentary-like in its depiction of this idiosyncratic family, which provides every minute with a sense of real involvement. The only problem that, in my view, ends up spoiling this cinematic endeavor is its lack of confidence in challenging the traditional structure that so brilliantly sets up. Specially in the third act, where it gets mixed and self-contended. Besides that, is an endearing movie that, in its core, is about family and coping with loss which is largely supported by a brisk screenplay. There's one line that specially struck me as it reinforced what I've been thinking: "Interesting is a non-word. You know you're never allowed to use it. Be specific.". And that's exactly how I feel. When I'm writing something, whether a paper or a review, I'm completely appalled by the word "interesting" as I find it devoid of content. What does that mean, "interesting"? It's a word you use when you can't say something either bad or good, it's a safeguard when you're too lazy to actually think about what makes the subject of your attention appealing. So, it's was fantastic to see this movie confirming what I strongly support and I make an appeal to all of you reading to replace "interesting" with someone as meaningful as the sense of family bonds in "Captain Fantastic". And that's it! My pre-Oscar reviews are done. Sorry, "Loving", "The Red Turtle" and "The Lobster". I'll get to you later...

Captain Fantastic is an indie film about a father raising six kids off the grid. He teaches them to provide for themselves and gives them an education. After losing his wife Ben tries to keep his family together while traveling to her funeral. They have some adventures on the way and the children learn some life lessons. Ben is somewhat a extremist. He is certain by this ideologies and is flawed because of it. He cut his family off out of the real world, he won't teach them important knowledge but raise them in his own beliefs. This comes around in the film later on and is addressed. 

Acting wise the children were good. All of the cast were great, there were some scenes that weren't good like when Bens son Justin was angry at him it just didn't seem believable. When he would act it would kind of put me out of the film for moment. George Mackay was excellent in this film, I really enjoyed his performance. Every scene he was in was great. 

The antagonist in this film is the Grandad. When they called about the death Bens wife they told him he isn't allowed to come to the children or he will phone the police. I didn't quite understand this threat because Ben wouldn't have done anything wrong. I figured the Grandfather had something on Ben, something he did. But there was never a reveal. As an antagonist, (apart from not allowing Ben to the funeral) he was one of the most reasonable people in the film. He wanted to bring the children into the real world, put them in school and provide them with a good life.
This movie tries way too hard and has a very unrealistic ending. Time I will never get back. I suggest you don't waste yours.

Captain Fantastic is an interesting film because one moment you're seeing the wisdom in Viggo Mortensen's character's way of parenting, and then the next moment you think he's completely insane. The child actors bring a lot to the table in this unconventional drama, too. I don't know what this movie was attempting to tell me, exactly, but I enjoyed myself while trying to figure it out.
Viggo Mortensen's performance is one for the ages. In a film, far from many 21st century dramas, Captain Fantastic gives a deep look into the lives of a family removed from society.
I liked it's message about how we live in the modern world, although there's a bit too much "fish out of water" humor and it's a bit much - "you speak 6 languages!" - okay....

I'm shook. I went into this film with absolutely no expectations, fully expecting some Caucasian Hipster Indie Movie bullshit. The trailer and the poster do it absolutely NO favors in that respect. What I found instead was a brilliantly written and conceived, beautifully performed drama that really does consider all angles of the repercussions of what this man is doing to his children. And while it is far fetched that all SEVEN of them turned out to be basically superhumans as a result of their parents' training, the kids are good enough to really sell it, and it makes you question your own conception of what society's institutions should look like, or if at least it should be allowed for the will of the group to reject that and carve their own paths. Bra-fucking-vo.

This movie is in my top ten favorite movies. The story is compelling, the characters are lovable unique individuals, each one leaving a lasting impression, the plot moves, and the laughs are often. On top of that, there is something special about a movie that you find yourself thinking about in detail later, and that makes you question your life (without feeling preachy). It's not a glorified view of the lifestyle either, but challenges it on many levels. Many articles however display a complete misunderstanding of the ideologies of this movie. It is not a liberal's dream, but much more closely aligned with an enlightened version of libertarian, if anything it is a much needed middle ground point of view combining liberal and libertarian views.

The film excels by treating a beaten subject, cliché, and involving with a depth and meaning that you do not even feel the charged charge until you actually reach it. The film leaves that subject in the background for the most part ... to where you already admire Ben and his way of life, in the education of his children away from society, in the search to shape them differently from the society and family considered as conventional . You are seduced by the character of Viggo, perfect in his Ben ... who before being a father is also a leader, captain ... just, open ... agregador, fierce in the creation of his children. The young cast lavishes talent and charisma, with each having its own characteristic and certain depth that allied to his particular talent, gave an air of truth that is impossible not to be enchanted. The dilemmas, pros and cons of such a creation thus come to the fore most sharply with the need for confrontation with established society, with the eldest son's questioning of his lack of "social tact" in ordinary situations of young people of his age, and also in his personal growth outside the cell created by Ben. Film of a promising Matt Ross, who does not care to point out the right or wrong, the good the evil .. an impartiality ... but that makes clear the razor wire that is the human being look for his own navel, to the detriment of seek his truth. his reason for being. Which seems to be more in the middle of the forest. Great !!

Well I never thought this day would come but a hippie movie is my favorite film of 2016. Captain Fantastic is about a man named Ben who raises his 6 kids in the forrest in the Pacific Northwest however after his wife dies, they decide to go to her funeral however he has to deal with his kids adjusting with a world outside the environment of the forrest. However the plot to the movie is just so much more than just that because its like a social commentary on life, education, religion, raising a family, etc and I love how different it is. Viggo Mortensen plays the father in this film and he is a revelation in this role this may be his best performance to date. However what really surprised me in this movie was the actors who played the 6 kids because though they are really a supporting part of the movie they are in almost every scene which is a lot of weight to carry but they did great. Also Frank Langella who I find underrated does great in this film as well along with Kathryn Hahn and Steven Zahn. Though I gave this film a perfect score its definitely not for everyone, the film kind of criticizes on how we are under educated and on religion a little because like I said earlier in this review it kind of points out a lot of things about society, but it also makes you think a little and thats what I love about this film. My one main issue with this film is probably towards the end because its just a little bizarre for me but I guess thats what they were aiming for considering the movie itself is bizarre and not necessarily your typical average family film. Captain Fantastic is a smart and different film, I can't really guarantee whether or not you will love this movie, the only reason I gave it five stars is because I appreciate that it was different, so I will say this if you are looking to get out of your comfort zone than I would recommend giving Captain Fantastic a try and see what you think.

The temptation to drop out of society runs strong in the US (see also Sean Penn's excellent Into the Wild, 2007) - and who could blame 'em? Here we find Viggo Mortensen raising his six children in the woods of the Pacific Northwest and who wouldn't cheer his efforts to strengthen their bodies and minds while avoiding the contamination of capitalism, organized religion, and junk food? The film isn't called "Captain Fantastic" for nothing!  But Matt Ross's script (he also directed) gradually forces viewers to confront the possibility that this Super-Dad is actually doing his kids harm by keeping them away from the social world they will eventually have to live in (and exposing them to the truth of adult concepts too soon).  But I'm not so sure - is it either or?  Do we have to endorse the version of reality put forth by Frank Langella (capitalist Christian Grandpa) if we accept the premise that Chomsky-loving Viggo might be over-the-top?  Isn't there a happy medium? (The film seems to conclude that there is - but this outcome seems as much a fantasy - or cop out -- as the extreme outdoors approach taken earlier; how exactly are they supporting themselves?).  Viggo did have a raison d'etre of sorts - his wife had bipolar disorder and he thought living in the woods would help her (but it did not).  The six child actors acquit themselves admirably and almost without any cringeworthy moments (save only for their rendition of Sweet Child O' Mine at the "funeral", now a cliché, but one that did remind me of a long-departed dear friend). The film itself is fun and, although balanced precariously on just some exaggerated representations of deeper worldviews, it does succeed as a more thought-provoking version of the usual Hollywood entertainment.  I just wish that Matt Ross would have seen fit to show Viggo (or his kids) having an influence on the larger society (or at least Langella) rather than simply depicting their assimilation - but I guess that would be truly fantastical.

Still memorable one year later. This movie explores, one Father rejection of the World, to extent he chooses to bring up his own children away from the same consumerism , he so rejects and loathes. The irony, is that as much as he thinks he is trying to protect his children, from Worldy decay, it is this very same World, that his children must grow up to engage with, to deal with, to socialize with and within. it is as though, he seeks an imaginary world which does not exist, and so he seeks the same for his children. And yet, when his children grow up, it is this very same World, good or bad, hopeful or sad, that they must deal with, and not some imaginary world. Tough ideas, dealt w in a very tender way, w Father and children. Are we not all in the same boat? We hold our disdain to society false values, False heroes, sometimes we are living groundless ness, and yet, this is the very same World that our children must learn to survive in, and embrace, for better or worse. Are we simply doing them a disservice by shielding from the World? as it really is, not as imagined?

Ben (Viggo Mortensen) and Leslie Cash (Trin Miller) have long lived largely off the grid with their offspring - Bodevan, Kielyr, Vespyr, Rellian, Zaja and Nai - in a cabin in the mountains of Washington state. The parents have passed their ideals to their children, namely socialism (in its various forms) and survivalism. With the former, Ben considers most of western society as being fascist, especially corporate America. With the latter, he figures that no one will or should be there for you, so you better learn how to take care of yourself in all its aspects. As such, the children have been subject to vigorous physical training, know how to deal with minor bumps, bruises, cuts, sprains and even fractures, and know how to hunt, forage and grow their own food. The children are also non-registered home schooled, meaning that they have no official academic records. Ben and Leslie have tried to make the children critical thinkers, however within the context of their ideals. Beyond these issues, Ben and Leslie made the decision to live this lifestyle for Leslie's health. Formerly a lawyer, Leslie was diagnosed as bipolar. Ben figures that this disorder started with her post-partum depression with Bo. Even with this lifestyle, Leslie's condition has become progressively worse. Despite not believing in western medicine, Ben, to deal with the illness, has sent Leslie to hospital, one close to Ben's sister, Harper, in Sacramento so that there can be family close by. While in hospital, Leslie is able to commit suicide. Beyond the collective grief, Leslie's act brings out a battle between Ben, and Leslie's father, Jack Bertrang, a wealthy Christian, who not only blames Ben for what happened to Leslie, but believes what he is doing to the children can legally be considered abuse. To be held in their church in New Mexico, Jack takes over the funeral arrangements to his and his complacent wife Abby's Christian morals, against what Ben knows was Leslie's wishes, she who believed in Buddhist philosophies. Although Jack threatens to call the police if Ben shows up to the funeral, he and the children believe it is the latest of their missions to rescue Leslie to honor her last wishes to be cremated as per Buddhist philosophies. This mission not only may bring the divide between Jack and Ben to a head, but may also bring out some long seated issues within the Cash children as they are exposed to commercial America in all its good and bad, and as Bo grows into manhood, he who may have his own ideas of what he should do with the next phase of his life...

Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Captain Fantastic's thought-provoking themes-and an absorbing starring turn from Viggo Mortensen-add up to an above-average family drama with unexpected twists." Alonso Duralde of TheWrap gave the film a positive review, saying "The movie really belongs to Mortensen, who allows Ben to be exasperating, arrogant and impatient but also warm, loving and caring. He's a tough but adoring father, a grieving widower and a passionate defender of his wife's final wishes, and Mortensen plays all these notes and more with subtlety and grace". Peter Debruge of Variety gave the film a positive review, saying "Boasting half a dozen impressive youth performances alongside a leading role that takes full advantage of Mortensen's own sensitive, back-to-nature spirit, Captain Fantastic easily ranks among the most polished and relatable of this year's Sundance offerings." One of the few negative reviews was from Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian. "There's a meaty whiff of phoney-baloney in this fatuous and tiresome movie, replete with forced emotional crises and wrong notes, topped off with an excruciatingly unearned, sentimental ending. It's a low-cal version of Peter Weir's 1986 movie The Mosquito Coast, starring someone who is essentially a cross between Charles Manson and Captain von Trapp."

"Captain Fantastic" is emotional, existential, funny, gripping and sad with the focus on education, parenthood, norms and the difficulties of losing a partner and parent. I think that Viggo Mortensen gives one of his best performances as an actor and he literally becomes Ben in all ways. His portrayal of a devoted father, a leader, a teacher, a loyal and grieving husband with an honest approach to how his kids should grow up is magnificent. It´s a movie that wants you to question the way we live in the western society and what it does to us. To bring out all those questions we have but never really think that much about. At the same time the film is not taking sides, but rather display the different sides both good and bad. The direction is on the spot and director Matt Ross has managed to get excellent performances from all the main actors/actresses and the cinematography is quite beautiful. Ross has also chosen plenty of great songs for the soundtrack that binds together the film. Amongst the songs there´s a lovely version of Guns & Roses "Sweet Child of Mine". "Captain Fantastic" is a fine piece of film in my point of view.

Captain Fantastic is a joy of a film. It has some minor flaws but it has a huge heart and a strong emotional pull that overcomes those. Viggo Mortensen is truly superb as the inspiring father raising his six children off the grid in the Pacific Northwest. Mortensen is a grounded actor who fills his roles with a strong humanity. In this case his character is a man who firmly believes that modern society is too concerned with money and power and consumption to give his children a wholesome view of life. They live a wild and eccentric life that leaves them well rounded but also outcasts to society. When a family tragedy strikes they are forced to react with the world around them which causes family friction and a questioning of their lives. As said this film exudes heart and a beautiful energy. The film "Captain Fantastic" has proven that you don't need to add excessive, banal sexuality to spice up a film about an off-the-grid commune. The characters are all book-smart people who can have an intelligent discourse on politics or history while not knowing anything about big brands that have bombarded the rest of humanity. Other than the fact that this is a family drama, the talented fledgling actors who played the role of the children of Ben (Viggo Mortensen) also makes the film all the more interesting, especially when their innocence are juxtaposed with the vulgar display of 'capitalistic wealth' that is rampant everywhere when they go travel to attend their mother's funeral. I find this originality of the story, which has characters whose socio-political views are aligned to my own, intrinsically beautiful.

Truly a unique family drama that went from a rebellious, thematic nature that formed conflicted views towards the agreeable sense of morality all while within a coming-of-age tale from a father's unconventional perspective. It's a film with the usual heart under keyword conflicted, some humor to go along with it, and fine performances to express it as well, which is enough towards a satisfying resolution. (B+)

Captain Fantastic had an intriguing premise and was beautifully filmed, but unfortunately the script was so poor and cliche-ridden that I turned it off halfway through. Unbelievably precocious children spouting literary and philosophical references right out of the CliffsNotes; a family living off the land in the deep rainforest (good luck growing vegetables with 2 hours of direct sunlight a day for three months a year); somehow affording to drive a pristine school bus cross-country to a funeral; silly male rites of passage; cringe-worthy fireside jam sessions; pre-canned cultural critigues. I don't understand how people found it charming and informative. Rather, I found it somewhat insulting that Ross kept everything at a superficial level and never allowed his characters to have a real, meaningful conversation. The dialog was more like an exercise in combining Sorkinesque sanctimonious one upsmanship with Wes Anderson's preciousness. Not a pleasant combination in my opinion. 

Had Ross focused on building a believable life for the family, with all the inherent difficulties (malnutrition, interpersonal conflict, depression, isolation, money worries, broken down vehicles, infected bug bites and unhealed injuries) rather than an impossible neverland with a few minor inconveniences, he might have captured my interest. Instead I was focused on everything that was wrong with his picture. 

Maybe I missed the point. Maybe it was supposed to be a farcical send-up of the lefty homeschool crowd. In that case, it also did a poor job, as I didn't find it particularly humorous in its literalness and lack of subtlety. 

I'd love to see a similar plot in the hands of a more capable and experienced director - someone who can construct believable dialog and demonstrates a little more restraint. But this is not it.

I don't know about the Captain, but his kids are pretty fantastic. This is a simple little film that is more than meets the eye, and certainly smarter than your average bear. The story is about a bohemian/survivalist guy raising his pack of kids almost totally off the grid, and doing one hell of a job at it. These kids are capable of debating the finer points of Trotskyism and slicing your jugular with equal skill and flair. This clan is totally bizarre and at first is easily dismissed as a bunch of nutty hippies, maybe even cult-ish. But as the film progresses, you start to question who is 'right' in how they live their lives. He teaches his children with a disarming candor that is comedic, refreshing, and disturbing at the same time. His bluntness makes the viewer painfully aware of how it's not only normal, but expected to lie or withhold the truth from others... particularly our children, all in the name of social propriety. On the other side of the argument, though his kids are fiercely intelligent and capable, they are completely inept at dealing with modern society at large, or anyone in it. This film has a lot to say about American values and society, but is never judgmental, preachy or manipulative. It just presents both the merits and dangers of conformity in the context of the story and lets the viewer come to his/her own conclusion. The story is intelligent and well-written, and has more layers and goes in different directions than you'd expect. The acting is also great by all parties, and Viggo Mortensen nails it as the paterfamilias (I don't know that his performance is worthy of the Best Actor nod he received, but he's very good). The direction also adds to the themes, giving the scenes in the 'natural' environment a documentary vibe by shooting with a handheld camera, and contrasting that by using a steadicam to film the 'normal' commercial world, which emphasizes its artificiality. There is lots of food for thought here, but there is also enough humor to lighten up the sometimes somber subject matter, and a heaping ton of heart. If nothing else, it will challenge your ideas about parenting. It's not the best movie I've ever seen, or even one of the best, but it definitely makes you think.

We have a man with 6 kids living in the wild. We slowly find out how and why this is happening, along with where the wife and mother is. 
I hate how Bens(Viggo) ideas, now matter how good and thought out, are dismissed by "normal" people because he's a supposed hippie living in the wild. I imagine it's easier to do that than to make your self uncomfortable with them. Cognitive dissonance big time. 
He's anti-establishment, anti-religion, anti-technology, anti- big everything. He takes it too far, of course, and raises incredibly smart and tough kids who are woefully unprepared for dealing with "normal" people, and the more modern ways of life. 
I don't like it how it paints things a bit too black and white. Like how the kids of his relatives are cliche slaves to their phones and video games, and are dolts in regards to education. 
People CAN appreciate many different aspects of culture and  society to be well rounded individuals. You can use tech, and still love to play in nature. 
All parents raise their kids as little versions of themselves. It's just the way we do things. The key is to recognize this, and not force our own personal mindsets on them. Teach them HOW to think, not WHAT to think. 
I do recommend this for people who might like some strange with their thoughtful family dramas.

There's one reason, and one reason only, for why I wanted to watch this movie.  I love Viggo Mortensen.  I also love Frank Langella and Kathryn Hahn (though they're supporting characters).  Actually, I guess there's FOUR reasons.  Seriously though, I've been on a pretty rotten run of movies lately (one of which was one of the worst movies I've seen in months).  It's been about 9 days since I reviewed a movie that I thought was good (that'd be Catfight) and I just wanted to watch something that I knew would be good.  I mean, I didn't really know that this would be good.  There's always a chance that a movie you think you might enjoy would end up falling short of those expectations, but I digress.  Thankfully, however, this ended up being a really damn good movie in ways that I didn't really expect.  I watched the trailers and I honestly didn't really even know what to expect.  Not saying that they were misleading, but just that they didn't give you the sense of what the film is actually about.  Long story short, the film sees Ben and Leslie move their children away from civilization, where they're taught survivalist skills, philosophy and to be self-dependent.  Leslie, however, has been struggling with depression and Ben thought moving her and the children away from the hectic city life to a more secluded, nature-friendly place would help Leslie with her depression.  It didn't and Leslie is interned in this psychiatric facility in order to get the help she needs.  Ben's father-in-law pays for her stay in the hospital.  Anyway, Leslie kills herself and this is where the film really starts.  The film is about Ben's journey with his children to go to her funeral, despite being prohibited by Leslie's father from attending.  The movie is very interesting in how it explores a variety of different subjects of this family dynamic.  While the way Ben raises his children makes them stronger, more self-reliant, allows for critical thinking without any fear of judgement and, quite frankly, more intelligent than most adults, it also raises questions in whether or not his methods are putting his children in danger.  There are several scenes where you get to see how his teachings and how his approach to parenting leads to one of his daughters finding herself in an incredibly dangerous situation, where she could have been paralyzed or even died.  Regardless of how smart and self-reliant Ben's children are, there's also some sense that he's really not even letting them be children.  Another aspect is the fact that, in spite of what Ben teaches, he just hasn't prepared them for how the real world works.  His oldest son, as an example, struggles to connect with this girl he meets.  He even says that, if it doesn't come from a book, he knows nothing about life.  The film also explores how one of Ben's sons just strives to have some sense of normalcy and how he lashes out in anger when he's frustrated.  It's certainly a very interesting (which is a banned word in this family) approach to tell this story, even if it's not gonna re-invent the wheel, but I like the fact that the movie isn't afraid to take chances with its characters.  Ben isn't portrayed as a perfect father.  I think one of the many themes the film explores is that, how, in part, he has failed his wife and his children in not trying to find a balance between teaching them to be self-reliant and knowing how the world actually works.  But there's also the other side of the equation and that is Leslie's family and their complete disregard and disrespect for her wishes upon her death.  Leslie was a Buddhist, she abhorred all forms of organized religion and how she wished to be cremated and flushed down the toilet.  So, Leslie's father and mother, not giving one ounce of a shit, gave her a Christian funeral and burial anyway.  This is when Ben and his children show up to crash the funeral, as it were, which is a completely depressing and solemn affair.  Ben gives a speech completely tearing apart this funeral and how this is a complete show of disrespect towards what Leslie would have wanted.  Leslie's father is outraged, even though he's the one who's really fucking up by not honoring his deceased daughter's wishes.  This sets off another element of the film, which sees Ben and his father-in-law fight over what is best for the children.  Eventually, when Ben sees the dangers he is exposing his children to, he decides to leave them with their grandfather.  Things don't go as planned, obviously, and the kids sneaked back into the bus.  This is when they decide to dig up their mother's coffin and give her the proper ceremony she wished for.  And, honestly, this scene is just downright lovely.  It might have felt a little sentimental, but I thought it worked because it celebrated Leslie's life instead of the way she died, the family sang her favorite song (Sweet Child O' Mine) and danced.  The contrast between this scene and the Christian funeral she was given was obvious.  And, when I go, I think this is really the best way to go about it.  Celebrate my life and not how it ended.  Laugh, smile, sing and dance.  The casting of this film is fantastic.  Viggo Mortensen is phenomenal, as he typically is.  The children are all fantastic as well and their chemistry is top-notch.  The writing finds some new little twists and a fresh perspective in the typical family-drama dynamic.  I don't know if I can say that all of this adds to a great movie, though.  Don't get me wrong, if this isn't great, then it's about as close as you can get to it without actually being great.  Don't let the fact that I don't think it ever reaches real greatness dissuade you from watching this.  I'd highly recommend this movie, there's very little, if anything, to dislike about this movie. An indie film is a (usually) low budget, unpopular, and unconventional film. Essentially, it's not going to be recognized by the masses, at least in the beginning of it's lifetime. Captain Fantastic could not be any more indie if it tried: it's attack on what is considered conventional behavior, and an attack on America's own vanity. Ben (Viggo Mortensen) has been raising his kids with his wife in the wilderness for a decade, shielding them from the media that younger generations are exposed to. In turn, they're all incredibly well-read with Olympian bodies and a raw outlook on life. Viggo Mortensen's bravura is entrancing, and the children are all excellent as well. With sweeping vistas of northwest America and a stunning soundtrack, it's also a technical achievement. The ideals presented here made me question my own ways of life, and these are the most valuable kinds of films. Captain Fantastic is a beautiful and sobering film that made me laugh and cry at the same time, and I'm so thankful that it was made.

Viggo Mortensen stars in Captain Fantastic. Mortensen is Ben, a man who is raising his kids in the forest. He teaches them how to hunt and survive on their own in the wilderness. He educates and home schools all of them, and because of it they can criticize literature, cite history, and even speak 6 languages. The oldest son has offers from all the top universities in the country. When their mother commits suicide, they must migrate to the city and face the real world. 

As they journey through civilization, the children have to interact with the world, and are exposed to modern elements, technology and things they do not understand. Ben is completely open and does not even hide or sugar coat anything to his children even if it regards sex, death, suicide, or simply drinking wine under age. Their aunt challenges him and says they belong in a modern school, he proves her otherwise as they can recite more than either of her sons. What is clearly lacking is the sense of communication and interaction. This is demonstrated the oldest son first interacts with a girl and has no idea what to do. At one point is Ben's method of raising his children truly superior and borders on what many others would consider to be child abuse. When two of his children suffer injuries and his parents grandfather question his tactics, he truly begins to question his own parenting methods. 

Captain Fantastic is an intriguing film that is original and has an independent and non-Hollywood driven feel to it. The film stars off by wowing you with the way the children behave and you are impressed by their knowledge. The comparisons and shots it takes at the modern education system, and religion indeed have some relevance. The film also comments on the obesity of children and the status of healthcare. Had the film pressed on these more and brought more of light to these issues would have made the film more compelling. Mortensen's performance which is academy nominated is worth watching as he does help drive would have been a dreadfully boring film. He shows a complete range emotion and you feel for him and his children and get the sense he does care for his children, but many sometimes get in his own way. It is a tough film to recommend and Captain Fantastic will not sit well with most audiences, and I too wished the film had a bit more to offer.

An unusual tale of a family cast outside of modern society, that whist proving a relatively entertaining watch, poses a number of thought provoking questions about life and our surroundings as we know it. Viggo Mortensen plays a father to his six children, and along with the help of his wife, have devoted themselves to the wild, and a more rural way of life. Social norms are challenged, whilst an uplifting and accepting undertone runs throughout.

"Captain Fantastic" is the tale of a family that moves into the wilderness to avoid the societal woes created by politics, religion, and materialism.  It is one of my favorite films of 2016 and is completely underrepresented at the Oscars.  It strikes a good balance of comedy, drama, impressive acting, beautiful scenery, and a moral about the importance of family.  I found its tone to be reminiscent of "Little Miss Sunshine."  You may think that it's because the story centers around a slightly dysfunctional family on a road trip, but it comes mostly from the themes of family sticking together through the tough times.  The family dynamic is deep and real.  The interactions amongst the kids as well as their interactions with their father feel so legitimate that you'll forget that they are actors until you sit down to write a movie review (speaking from personal experience).  Viggo Mortensen gives the performance of his career with a broad array of emotions as well as strong chemistry with every character surrounding him.  The remainder of the cast is rounded out by talented child actors an ensemble of character actors including Steve Zahn, Kathryn Hahn, and Frank Langella.  All of the quirky characters are the brainchild of Writer/Director Matt Ross.  I would've loved to see his screenplay get an Oscar nomination if not for the neverending stream of unnecessary f-words.  These cheapen the heartwarming story of family and standing up for what you believe in.  Without the profanity (and more of Viggo than we ever needed to see), this would have made a great PG-13 film that parents and teens could enjoy together.  "Captain Fantastic" is a highly entertaining story filled with great acting and a strong moral as long as you can get past all of the f-words.  I wish that more of 2016's Oscar films could have found this balance between drama and comic relief.

Captain Fantastic plays out like a mashup of an outback America Swiss Family Robinson & Little Miss Sunshine.  Except not as funny, or as frivolous.  The plot - by first time writer/director, and tv actor Matt Ross in his very first big league Hollywood movie - cocoons the Cash family sans mother/wife Leslie (portrayed in hallucinations by Trin Millers) living their lives off the grid, in the isolated outback of Washington (nature and wilderness scenes captured beautifully by Ross).  Where the family - including  5 year old Nai - learn to kill animals/deer for food; where they live in a cool,  hand constructed, fort-like structure; where the kids are homeschooled like "philosopher kings" taught Mao, Stalin, Trotsky, Plato and Chomsky. 

Thought provoking ideas, commentary and character activity of the Cash clan plays out through an absorbing performance by Best-Actor nominated Viggo Mortensen as father/leader Ben as well as a cast of 6 terrific child/teen actors including George MacKay (last seen in Pride), Annalise Basso (Oculus, Ouija: Origin of Evil), Samantha Isler (with such a gorgeous alt-indie voice) et al.  
It's an existentialist family re-origin adventure that harks back to actions and behaviors of Native American pioneers living off the land, adopting an anti-modern, non-consumerist lifestyle with minimal ecological damaging footprints.
As the Wikipedia synopsis shares:

"Ben and Leslie are disillusioned with capitalism and American life, and chose to instill survivalist skills, left wing politics, and philosophy in their children - educating them to think critically, training them to be self-reliant, physically fit and athletic, guiding them without technology, demonstrating the beauty of coexisting with nature and celebrating "Noam Chomsky Day" instead of Christmas."
Their life gets thrown for a loop when Leslie Cash dies, and the family has to LITERALLY jump on a converted school bus to travel to New Mexico to be "funeral"crashers after being denied access and inclusion by Leslie's rich father Jack, played with monosyllabic baritone gruff by Frank Langella.

The Cash's bus roadtrippin' through different States, as well as through big city civilization, captures with widescreen panorama the scenicness of barely touched natural landscapes juxtaposed with manmade, concrete jungles that our human presence has not only constructed but demanded in order to support our unstoppable consumeristic and manufactured existences.

A food-for-thought movie from beginning to end, Captain America stimulates us to envision living in a compromising, new world / old world mashed-up existence where one foot is firmly planted in the nourishing expansiveness of nature (from biological, psychological, and sustenance influences) and the other moored to present-day, contemporary advancement and subsistence.

You know what's ridiculous?  This movie only made $6m.  It's better than most movies I've seen in the last year.  I don't understand it.  Seriously.    You put this or Manchester by the Sea in front of me to watch....10 out of 10 times I'd watch this.

Here's the premise: "Deep in the forests of the Pacific Northwest, isolated from society, a devoted father (Viggo Mortensen) dedicates his life to transforming his six young children into extraordinary adults. But when a tragedy strikes the family, they are forced to leave this self-created paradise and begin a journey into the outside world that challenges his idea of what it means to be a parent and brings into question everything he's taught them."

It's a thought provoking premise...teaching your children to be the best of the best...the most well educated, introspective children...able to survive on their own...kill a deer, no problemo...scale a wall, easy peasy...but what happens when your actual universe is limited to your family?  It's brilliant and whipsaws your thoughts from "this is awesome, I wish I could have lived like this" to "wtf...they have no clue of the real world."  But is the success in the "real" world really something to strive for?  Is it something that makes you happy?  Without real world skills, are you really guiding your children to ultimate happiness?  All good stuff.

The performances here are good.  Viggo Mortenson is excellent as usual.  He plays the introspective understated character better than almost anyone.  He's up for an Oscar for his role here.

I can't imagine anyone not liking this movie.  It has heart...and thought...and beauty.  It has one of the best closing 15 minutes of any movie this past year.  If you have Amazon Prime, it's like $6.  Well worth it.   I'm a fan...see it.

Captain Fantastic was directed by Matt Ross and stars Viggo Mortensen (Lord of the Rings, A History of Violence) as Ben, a father of six raising his children in the Washington forests away from American society. When he learns that his hospitalized wife has committed suicide, Ben takes his kids into the city, which is met to much criticism from his in-laws.

I'll start off by saying that Captain Fantastic is a very original movie. The idea of a family successfully living in the wilderness for years is baffling, and the results are clearly different from the city folk. His children are raised to think critically, stay in shape, and learn survival skills, but their social skills suffer greatly. I really enjoyed all of the earlier scenes in the wilderness, capturing the sounds and beauty of nature, while the cities felt mysterious by comparison through the children's eyes. The standout of this movie is Viggo Mortensen. His moral fiber as a father is attacked, and we see his internal struggle first-hand. The children also give good performances as they seem to have great chemistry with one another and Viggo.

While I did enjoy this movie, I have to admit that it seems a little ridiculous. The family has a lot of ideals about how the world doesn't work, but the kids almost immediately discard those thoughts in favor of living in society and receiving a normal education. Also, it's a bit odd that a family of seven can live out in the wilderness for years without ever being discovered or needing to venture into the cities for any resources.

I must reiterate that I did enjoy Captain Fantastic. It's an original and emotional movie filled with drama and subtle humor. However, the lack of reality is obvious, though it's easy to ignore thanks to Viggo. If the premise intrigues you, go watch Captain Fantastic!

Final grade: B

-Ben

A quirky little indie film about a man named Ben (Viggo Mortensen) who along with his wife is raising their six children in the wilds of the Northwest Pacific. The kids are extremely fit, know how to hunt, are grades beyond their level in education, but know little of social skills in the "outside" world. Ben has created a world for them to run away from the outside world where theres cell phones, televisions, bad food and politics. After a tragic event happens Ben takes the kids and journeys to the city to confront his wife's parents and to fully realize what exactly is best for his children. The movie looks good. It's shot really well and there's a great use of colors especially later in the film that show the difference with the family compared to everyone else. Mortensen shines as the lead actor in the film and is believable as some sort of hippie living out in the wild, but a very strong and protective father figure. The kids all have great personalities of their own and present the questions of why? Why do they do this? Why don't they live a seemingly "normal" life? It's a film with a lot of heart that I enjoyed. The gripes I had with it are that its second act is a little slow and I felt like the very last half happens a little too quick. Ben makes a decision and its resolved literally 5 minutes later. I would have liked it to be a bit more dramatic for those moments. Overall, definitely worth a rent if it sounds interesting to ya!

Captain Fantastic is one of my favorite movies of 2016! It delivers a beautiful message, it has a delightful cast (the kids are just amazing), with Viggo Mortensen stepping up his game (Oscar, please?) and an adventure-full story that still manages to end on a very bright note.

A wonderful movie about the true meaning of family. Matt Ross wrote and directed this film and it turned out perfect. Everyone from the veteran actors to the children just starting out are amazing in this movie. The screenplay is stellar, the cinematography is solid, the direction is oscar worthy and Viggo Mortensen hasn't done a movie this good since Lord of The Rings. The movie basically blows your mind in every way which is exactly why I'm giving Captain Fantastic a 10/10.
